Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a multifunctional x-ray diffractometer (XRD) for research (materials and geology) and education
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant will support the acquisition of a multifunctional x-ray diffractometer, enhancing research and student training at California State University, San Bernardino (CSUSB). This system will be used across a broad range of disciplines. In physics and chemistry, it will contribute to research on the development of new technological materials, including novel magnetic and ferroelectric systems. In geology, it will be an important tool in student and faculty research, primarily for the identification and characterization of rocks and minerals. Work performed using this instrument will significantly enhance the research infrastructure at CSUSB, particularly by furthering access to many experimental techniques (e.g. powder and thin film diffraction, reflectometry) applicable to a wide range of sample types (e.g. thin films, powders, polymers). CSUSB is an undergraduate-focused university and a qualifying Hispanic- and Minority-Serving Institution; thus, acquisition of this instrument will broaden participation of students from underrepresented demographics in state-of-the-art research, with a long-term impact of increasing diversity in STEM fields. Additionally, the ability to provide access to an advanced x-ray diffraction system will support the development of local collaborations with many institutions, including community colleges, other four-year universities, and local industries. Many of these education institutions and industries also serve minority populations that are underrepresented in the physical sciences, compounding the impact of this instrumentation in the development of a diverse STEM pipeline in the local area.

The diffractometer will be utilized for a variety of x-ray scattering techniques. Some of the major features of the instrument include a precision sample positioning stage and Eulerian cradle, enabling the performance of powder, thin film, and grazing incidence diffraction and reflectometry. A Ge monochromator and pixel area detector will allow for high-resolution scanning and rapid collection of reciprocal space maps, and a multi-position automatic sample chamber will permit the rapid and automatic collection of powder diffraction patterns. These capabilities for rapid data collection and multi-sample analysis will significantly augment the team's research productivity, allowing time for more projects and broader impact of the machine. The diffractometer will enhance research output at CSUSB's NSF-CREST funded Center for Advanced Functional Materials (CAFM). The focus of the work will include: engineering novel ferroelectric and magnetic properties into single-crystal oxide thin films using epitaxial strain and multilayer geometry; optimizing organic ferroelectrics through preparation as thin films and novel polymer composites; and the identification and characterization of rocks and minerals in field and laboratory studies in geology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This MRI grant was used to fund the acquisition and commissioning of a multifunctional x-ray diffractometer. This system will be used for research within the department of Physics, Chemistry & Biochemistry, and Geology at California State University San Bernardino (CSUSB). The materials. This diffractometer will enhance CSUSB?s NSF-CREST funded Center for Advanced Materials (CAFM) by expanding the x-ray scattering measurement capabilities available on campus. In addition to an upgraded powder diffraction system, the new instrument can perform high resolution diffraction suitable for studying thin films and performing reciprocal space maps, reflectivity scans for thin films and multilayers, and small angle scattering for polymer samples. Several goals of the second phase of CREST funding have the CAFM expand into thin films and polymers more in depth, making the acquisition of the instrument a timely addition to allow these research areas to be supported with on campus access to invaluable characterization methods. The newly acquired system also includes a multi-sample change for powder samples as well as an area detector, which both enable measurements to be made more rapidly allowing for more users and an enhanced throughput of samples. This system will also lead to additional opportunities for students at CSUSB, a Hispanic-Seriving Institute (HSI) to participate in state-of-the-art research and develop experimental and instrumentation skills beneficial for participation in the STEM workforce. 

During the year this grant was active, a new SmartLab system was purchased from RIgaku and installed and commissioned on the CSUSB campus. After comparing systems from vendors, the purchase was made in late 2019 and delivered/installed in June 2020. This was slightly delayed from the estimated delivery/installation in April 2020 due to Covid-19 shutdown orders limiting the personnel allowed on campus. Installation was performed by a Rigaku technician and training was held virtually over Zoom with a Rigaku scientist. The SmartLab system is equipped to perform multiple types of x-ray scattering measurements: powder diffraction can be performed with both a basic sample stage and six-sample changer, stages can be used to perform high resolution x-ray diffraction, and the sample stage and n adjustble detector to perform transmission diffraction as well as preliminary small-angle scattering measurements. The area detector allows for fast counting over a range of angles, meaning that two-dimensional scans such as reciprocal space maps can be completed in minutes, rather than hours. This new system is vastly upgraded in terms of measurement capabilities and counting time from an older powder diffractometer that was also acquired from an MRI grant roughly 25 years ago and was heavily used by researchers and students in physics and geology. However, due to the system?s age and expansion of research areas in those departments it was no longer sufficient enough for heavy utilization. 

Once the CSUSB faculty members/grant PIs were fully trained, they began training research students and the new diffractometer has been heavily used by research groups in physics and geology. The machine has been regularly utilized since training was completed and has become a regular part of research for two of the proposal PIs. Usage is somewhat limited due to Covid-19 restricting which personnel on campus and limiting hours for research faculty and students. We anticipate that the number of users will grow significantly one these restrictions are relaxed. Additionally the Department of Chemistry & Biochemistry hired a new faculty member, physical chemist Dr. Joyce Pham, who started in Fall 2020. Her work involves the synthesis of novel solid-state materials and she will be able to use the new instrument as part of her work and the acquisition of the system helped attract her interest in working at CSUSB.

So far, 8 students (7 undergraduate, 1 graduate) have been trained on using the instrument and are cleared to independently use it for research. As an HSI, CSUSB is well positioned to help increase the diversity of who participates in the STEM workforce. Of the 8 students who have so far been using the new instrument, 6 are Hispanic and 6 are first-generation college students. Once in-person courses are allowed to resume on campus, the new diffractometer will be utilized in upper division coursework in the physics and geology departments.

The new diffractometer also complements the research activities of the CSUSB Center for Advanced Functional Materials (CAFM). The CAFM is funded by the NSF CREST program and was recently awarded a second found of funding (grant #1914777), which started in early 2020. Research strains that are expanded in this new phase include a larger emphasis on thin films (both of organic materials as well as functional oxides) and functional polymers (a new avenue at CSUSB). The new instrument has capabilities that can be used to study films (reflectivity, high resolution diffraction, grazing incidence diffraction) and polymers (small angle scattering) that were not previously available on campus.
